Josh Werner

results.content:
The instructor was introducing tags that he didn't understand and had to look at official resources to find out what they did and how to use them. The teaching style needs to be improved, the tutor needs to learn about the content and prepare the lesson before teaching it, I think it's fine to show other resources.

The 10-page final project mentioned in lesson 12 isn't added, yet. 

The second video introduced text editors, which involved a google search for text editors, which is OK. Looking at a more reliable source for the most widely used development tools e.g.:

https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2018/#technology-most-popular-development-environments

Web developers (click the tab) use Visual Studio Code, which wasn't mentioned. VS Code is free (open source), cross-platform (Windows, Mac and Linux) and lightweight (loads quickly). It is the tool I use and would highly recommend for beginner upwards.
results.content_html:
The instructor was introducing tags that he didn't understand and had to look at official resources to find out what they did and how to use them. The teaching style needs to be improved, the tutor needs to learn about the content and prepare the lesson before teaching it, I think it's fine to show other resources.

The 10-page final project mentioned in lesson 12 isn't added, yet.

The second video introduced text editors, which involved a google search for text editors, which is OK. Looking at a more reliable source for the most widely used development tools e.g.:

https://insights.stackoverflow.com/survey/2018/#technology-most-popular-development-environments

Web developers (click the tab) use Visual Studio Code, which wasn't mentioned. VS Code is free (open source), cross-platform (Windows, Mac and Linux) and lightweight (loads quickly). It is the tool I use and would highly recommend for beginner upwards.

results.content:
The course involved a lot of add HTML tags, but not explaining WHY they were being added, or in what case you'd use them.
 
For example, MAMP was installed, but it was never actually used or explained why you'd need to install it in the first place, a button tag was added that didn't do anything, and that was just glossed over, no explanation as to the differences between <b> and <strong>, <i> and <em>

results.content:
There is very little explanation of what is happening and why.  On many occassions the tutors says "OK, now I'm going to type H1" but doesn't really say why he is doing that.  In the part about lists there is no indication as to why the heading is inside the list.  It is also unclear why we were asked to install MAMP at the start as most browsers will happily read the HTML file from the filesystem without a server running.

I have now watched through to the end and the final 2 videos basically involve putting some images on a page and building an advert for this guys own website.

I will be making a note to myself to not bother with future "courses" from this user.
results.content_html:
There is very little explanation of what is happening and why. On many occassions the tutors says "OK, now I'm going to type H1" but doesn't really say why he is doing that. In the part about lists there is no indication as to why the heading is inside the list. It is also unclear why we were asked to install MAMP at the start as most browsers will happily read the HTML file from the filesystem without a server running.

I have now watched through to the end and the final 2 videos basically involve putting some images on a page and building an advert for this guys own website.

I will be making a note to myself to not bother with future "courses" from this user.

results.content:
The course is okay. You wont be getting any real world websites made doing this course. The majority of what is taught here is he generally demonstrates a tag (in a non practical example) by picking a tag and tossing it on a page with text in-between.  I dont think the examples here are all that impressive or practical. It also felt very repetitive with him just picking a random tag, writing text in between to see what it does. That is pretty much the whole course. I also dislike how he would make a mistake and not attempt to fix them, but would instead just copy / paste working code from MDN. 

To improve this course I would recommend the instructor adds a video where he creates an actual website with the html he is demonstrating, shows you the best practice for html5 semantics, and actually help you visualize what these tags are for. It could have been better if after his broad overview of the tags he did something with them (ie; practical website). I also wish he explained the WHY behind which tags to use, so we can get a deeper understanding. The way he taught made me feel like I might as well teach myself because he isn't explaining hardly anything. Just pick a tag, type text between, and see what it does. But no in-depth explanation for when or why to use this tag over other tags.

So, overall it is an okay course, but nothing I would actively recommend to anyone since it lacks the practical aspect of making a website. BTW: The final pdf file for html guide, is unavailable.

response.content:
First of all the exercises are practical.  1 This is how I learned the entire HTML5 Library of Tags was repetition it's also the way I benched press 300lbs repetition.  The idea that I show you 5 tags and you know HTML is not practical at all.  Also I do give an in Depth explanation of what each tag does because it is very important you understand what each tag does.  I am a Front End Developer with a job and I got the job by learning the way I taught.  I have no problem with bad reviews if there reasonable in this case your way off and are misleading people with you inaccurate posting.  Finally your last statement is false as well as the final PDF as you call it which is the HTML5 Reference Guide does in fact work.

Thanks for your long review I look forward to seeing you spend 10 hours producing a course and getting garbage feedback.

Let me add one more thing I work in the real world and manage over 100 websites I think I have a great understanding of what is required to get a job in Front End Development.

results.content:
Its a decent base to start with. However, there are a couple of suggestions I'll give for future viewers and videos made by this author.

For users, play the videos on x1.25 or x1.5. Or keep skiping until he finishes writing lines of code or demonstrations. 

For the author, keep being energetic. Your voice starts on most videos being loud and somewhat energetic, but as time goes on for every video, this changes heavily. It is specially noticed when you finish a video and the next one starts immediately. Also, split videos to avoid having >30mins long videos. Makes it easier to find stuff and to continue on a video that you left mid-way through, as it needs to buffer the whole video again.

I like that I didn't know a few stuff that I tagged with, but overall, if you know already html (even if its not advanced), provides very little use. For beginners, if you can grab this free, give it a go, else, try testing yourselves and use w3school, which is what this author keeps using through most of the course.
results.content_html:
Its a decent base to start with. However, there are a couple of suggestions I'll give for future viewers and videos made by this author.

For users, play the videos on x1.25 or x1.5. Or keep skiping until he finishes writing lines of code or demonstrations.

For the author, keep being energetic. Your voice starts on most videos being loud and somewhat energetic, but as time goes on for every video, this changes heavily. It is specially noticed when you finish a video and the next one starts immediately. Also, split videos to avoid having >30mins long videos. Makes it easier to find stuff and to continue on a video that you left mid-way through, as it needs to buffer the whole video again.

I like that I didn't know a few stuff that I tagged with, but overall, if you know already html (even if its not advanced), provides very little use. For beginners, if you can grab this free, give it a go, else, try testing yourselves and use w3school, which is what this author keeps using through most of the course.

Wost teaching ever, trust me I watched so don't pay for it.
Next course wrap the img tag inside a figure tag and instead of putting a bunch of sections for no reason try using the main tag first and then inside it you can use the divs and sections. HTML5 semantics are here for a reason and teaching people to structure a page the way you are teaching is actually driving the students to a wrong path.

results.content:
The tutor doesn't explain what he is doing as he goes. For example what is an 'h tag' 'anchor tag'? why does he type 'href' into the link tag? What is the 'target="_blank"' for in the link? Explains what to do but no explanation of the why or how it works.

Very poor for a course that is advertised as for complete beginners.
results.content_html:
The tutor doesn't explain what he is doing as he goes. For example what is an 'h tag' 'anchor tag'? why does he type 'href' into the link tag? What is the 'target="_blank"' for in the link? Explains what to do but no explanation of the why or how it works.

Very poor for a course that is advertised as for complete beginners.

results.content: Very boring.  The instructor clearly didn't know all of what he was presenting and had to frequently refer to w3schools for further info on how a tag should work and what it should do.  you could do that yourself for free.

results.content: A lot of the code in the FORM section has just been copied and pasted from w3schools. That's fine I guess but it hasn't been tested. If you take his finished form and actually submit it, you'll see that a lot of the data isn't submitted. Also instead of having one big form he's three different ones on a page. Confusing for new learners I think

response.content:
Daragh,

Thanks for your review what could I do to explain things more clear for you?  I just want to say I have been where you are and I understand the steep learning curve of taking on a new skill.  I was doing the same thing you are now about 4 years ago to update my skills in HTML5.  Please send me any questions you have and I will be happy to help your understand.

Best Regards,

Josh Werner

results.content:
weak while using w3schools examples, yes it still a good way to make me learn by myself but sometimes I see that you don't understand what are they doing that made me lost as a learner.

you didn't cover all features of html5 as you don't go little in-depth in SVG or canvas and a lot more.

I prefer if you inspected a simple web page and demonstrate it in a complete lecture. 

I prefer if the course has any styling addition like an overview of Bootstrap or CSS.

still good in forms and tags description.

results.content: Un curso practico, centrado y bien estructurado, una introducción a las herramientas de HTML.5  y su utilidad en la creación de sitios web, de tal manera que te permite estructurar, organizar contenidos, e introducir elemento de multitudinaria( audio, imágenes, vídeos)
